title: In search of Jim Corbett's India, a land of pink gin and man-eating tigers
text:
Mrs Singh emerged from her house brandishing a gun. She raised the rifle, held it against her sari and took aim across the fields. All for dramatic effect. The gun wasn’t actually loaded, she told us as she brought it down. The rifle was used in the past to scare away wild elephants, but it hadn’t been deployed for years – with increasing traffic there were now very few animal incursions, she explained. Besides, she added, the gun was a treasured object. She held it out for us to try.

That was an enormous honour. The rifle once belonged to Jim Corbett, hunter of man-eating tigers, pioneering conservationist and author of compelling jungle tales.

The British-Irish naturalist was born in India, became an administrator for the Indian railways and between 1907 and 1938 shot around 33 big cats that had variously killed some 1,200 people. For this, and for his immense knowledge of jungle life, he became near legendary. India’s oldest national park, established in 1936, was partly of his making and was renamed in tribute to him shortly after his death in 1955 – remarkably, given current post-imperialist thinking, it remains the Jim Corbett National Park today. Reflecting Corbett’s acclaim beyond India, there’s even a species of south-east Asian tiger named after him: panthera tigris corbetti.
